title: 106_s548
content: The Act titled "Fallen Timbers Battlefield and Fort Miamis National Historic Site Act of 1999" defines key terms such as "historic site," "management plan," "Secretary," "management entity," and "technical assistance." The Act also includes findings and purposes for the establishment of the historic site. The 185-acre Fallen Timbers Battlefield in Lucas County, Ohio, was the site of a 1794 battle between General Anthony Wayne and Native American tribes. Fort Miamis, occupied by General Wayne's legion from 1796 to 1798, was later attacked by British troops in 1813. Both sites are listed as historic landmarks. The Fallen Timbers Battlefield in Ohio, designated as a National Historic Landmark in 1960, aims to recognize and preserve the site, link it to Fort Miamis, and interpret military history and Native American culture from 1794 to 1813. Assistance is provided to Ohio and nonprofit organizations for preservation and interpretation efforts. Establishment of Fallen Timbers Battlefield and Fort Miamis National Historic Site in Ohio as an affiliated area of the National Park System to preserve historical, cultural, and natural resources. Authorization for technical assistance to Ohio, political subdivisions, and nonprofit organizations for implementing the management plan. The historic site includes the Fallen Timbers Battlefield site and Fort Miamis Park site as depicted on a map available for public inspection. SEC. 5. ADMINISTRATION OF HISTORIC SITES. The historic site will be administered in accordance with National Park System laws, including the National Park Service Organic Act and the Historic Sites, Buildings, and Antiquities Act. The Secretary may enter into a cooperative agreement for technical assistance in preserving the Fallen Timbers Battlefield and Fort Miamis National Historic Site. Payments made by the Secretary will be subject to an agreement on the project's use. The Secretary, in consultation with the management entity and Native American tribes, will develop a general management plan for the historic site in accordance with National Park System laws. The plan must be completed within 2 years of funds being made available. The Secretary must provide a copy of the general management plan to the Senate and House committees within 30 days of its completion. SEC. 6. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS: Funds necessary for carrying out this Act can be appropriated.
